column4: How can I turn off daemons? Things start up automatically when I boot, and I would like to turn them off, but I have no idea how. I think they're daemons. I tried an uninstall of Zope, and it is now only partially uninstalled. I think daemons are the problem? Someone put a bug note here: https://launchpad.ubuntu.com/malone/tasks/651/
zope being broken shouldn't affect anything else.
anyway, if your original question is "How do I stop some daemons running on boot?", just delete the S symlinks from /etc/rc2.d/
it's how init systems work on all modern unix systems
in ubunut/debian, the theory is that you don't install things if you don't want to run them
this problem has nothing to do with "daemons running
If daemons aren't the problem, then what do you think is the problem? This relates to https://launchpad.ubuntu.com/malone/tasks/651/
good on you for finding the bug report, btw
thanks
it being uninstallable is presumably because the package is broken
it won't run anymore, but it won't cause problems with you installing zope from source, either

I believe you, and it's just on faith. Question: Could package removal of any particular package be impeeded by the program already running? I guess you're saying that Linux/Unix can do the removal with programs running? The reason I ask is that I think I saw a message from Synaptic about trying to close a daemon, but that failed because the "daemon manager" wasn't running. I don't see...
subprocess pre-removal script returned error exit status 1 is a generic error from the low-level package manegement tools (dpkg) that means the removal cleanup script screwed up somehow
you would have got that if the zope packages are screwed

The package wasn't completely removed. It makes me nervous. ;> Should I remove the remaining pieces manually? Do you think it would be worth trying to reinstall, then uninstall? I don't like pieces of broken stuff lying around.
Maybe I just overanalyse.
it depends on how broken it is
heh, I understand
without looking carefully at the bug report, I couldn't tell you, and I don't have time, sorry
NP.
Thanks for your help. I'm at least pointed in the right direction.

One last question, then. Would it make any difference if I reboot? I'm asking re Synaptic Package Manager: Right now, it's in a certain state where it says nothing is broken, etc. I might want to try that reinstall, or repair, or something. But, if I reboot, can that mess me up?
rebooting won't help or hinder
unless the problem was to do with zope running or something weird
